titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Catalogued Reports, Reports 11775-13948
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Catalogued Reports, Reports 11775-13948 FA739E

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-04-24 00:21:36 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Catalogued Reports, Reports 11775-13948

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.
Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Catalogued Reports are open for research with select reports restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: For descriptions of Ford Foundation Catalogued Reports, please refer to the following finding aids (arranged by Report Number):

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Catalogued Reports are arranged numerically by an arbitrary call number assigned during cataloging, from 1 to approximately 20,000.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In the early 1970s, the Ford Foundation's archives staff began to identify and catalog individual reports, policy and programming documents, and program evaluations in an effort to create an internal lending-library of useful documents. Many of the Catalogued Reports were physically culled from the former Foundation officers' and staff's archival collections of 'office files'. When those collections of 'office files' were later processed, and finding aids created, an appendix of "Reports Removed" (or, Reports Transferred") was added to the finding aids.
By 1977 the collection included more than 3,500 reports, and by 1979 some 5,000 reports had been cataloged.
Duplicated copies of the reports were also created on microfiche, and later microfilm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ford Foundation's Catalogued Reports collection includes policy and programming documents, program evaluations, and periodic program status reports produced by Foundation officers and staff, as well as consultants and grantees. Some published material produced by Ford Foundation grants is also included in the collection. The collection also includes some of the Ford Foundation's own publications, such as the Annual Reports and newsletters.

F. Champion Ward - Memoirs, (Reports 012126)

scopecontent.head: Abstract/Summary
scopecontent.p: Contains reminiscences and reflections on Mr. Ward's experience as a consultant and officer for the Ford Foundation. Written in lieu of an Oral History at the suggestion of Howard Dressner, Secretary of the Foundation.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frederick Champion Ward was born on December 29, 1910 in New Brunswick, New Jersey. He graduated from Oberlin College in 1932 and was awarded a master's in philosophy in 1935. He went on to earn a doctorate in philosophy from Yale in 1937. He taught philosophy and psychology from 1937 to 1945 at Denison University and, as Associate Dean, trained military officers for de-Nazification efforts in postwar Germany. After the war, Dr. Ward joined the faculty of the University of Chicago and served as Dean of the undergraduate Humanities Division from 1947 to 1954.

In 1954, Dr. Ward took leave from the university to travel to India for the Ford Foundation. Upon his return, he joined the Foundation as Director of the Overseas Development Program for the Middle East and Africa. He later became Deputy Vice President for International Programs. In 1965, he was promoted to Vice President of Education and Research, a position he held until 1967 when he became a Program Advisor to International Division's Office of the Vice President. He retired from the Foundation in 1977.
During the 1960s Dr. Ward served as Chairman of the White House Task Force on the Education of Gifted Persons and was a member of the UNESCO International Commission on the Development of Education.

After his retirement from the Foundation, Dr. Ward worked as a consultant for the World Bank, the Association of American Universities, and the Connecticut Board of Education. From 1978 to 1981, he was a senior consultant to the Board of the MacArthur Foundation and helped establish the "genius grant." Dr. Ward also served as Chancellor of the New School for Social Research in Manhattan from 1980 to 1983. He died on July 2, 2007 at the age of 96.

did.unittitle: "The Ford Foundation: The Formative Years" (1936-1956), Williiam Greenleaf (Reports 013606)

scopecontent.head: Abstract/Summary
scopecontent.p: "This study, an account of the Ford Foundation during its first two decades from 1936 to 1956, continues the author's earlier narrative dealing with the philanthropies of Henry, Edsel and Clara Ford."

Chapters: 1. A Broader Range; 2. Charting a Course; 3. Men and Issues; 4. A New Regime; 5. Frontiers of Philanthropy: The United States; 6. Frontiers of Philanthropy: the World Arena; 7. Under Challenge; 8. Foundation Titan; 9. The Pattern of Commitment; 10. Transition.
Accompanied by an unsigned and undated note describing the manuscript's history.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also Ford Foundation Log files: L56-333: Organization of Foundation material relevant to past Congressional hearings on tax-exempt foundations, William Greenleaf; L56-1111: History of the Ford family philanthropies which preceded establishment of the Ford Foundation, William Greenleaf, Consultant); L56-1112: "Bibliography of American Philanthropy since 1900", William Greenleaf, Consultant; and L57-1209: "History of the Ford Foundation, 1936-1956", William Greenleaf, Consultant.

William Greenleaf's "The Ford Foundation: The Formative Years (1936-1956)" manuscript is also accessible at the Henry Ford Museum/Benson Ford Research Center in Dearborn, Michigan: http://www.dalnet.lib.mi.us/henryford/docs/FordFoundationSubseries_Accession1189.pdf , and from the University of New Hampshire' Special Collections and Archives: https://www.library.unh.edu/find/archives/collections/william-greenleaf-papers-1917-1976 .
